Research Paper Environment-friendly heterogeneous poly(ionic liquid)s immobilized polyoxometalate catalysts towards the efficient oxidation of alkenes Qiao Liu Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Conceptualization a b Meirong Kang Validation a Weiguo Fang Validation a Hailong Liu Writing – review & editing Supervision a ⁎ Zhiwei Huang Writing – review & editing Supervision a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and Carbon Dioxide Utilization, State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, China State Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and Carbon Dioxide Utilization State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Lanzhou 730000 China aState Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and Carbon Dioxide Utilization, State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China bUniversity of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. A novel quaternization reagent of (1E,1′E)-1,1′-(1,4-phenylene)bis(N-(3-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)propyl)methanimine) (PP) was synthesized and used for the preparation of a series of poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs) via the quaternization reaction. These PILs were subsequently loaded with polyoxometalates (POMs) to create innovative catalysts for the oxidation of alkenes. Comprehensive structural analysis of the catalysts showed that these PILs exhibited a high loading amount ratio of up to 542 % for POMs, which were well-dispersed on the surface of PILs. The PILs loaded POMs catalysts, especially for PW-PIL-TB-2PP with H3PW12O40 as the POMs, displayed remarkable activity and stability in oxidizing cyclooctene, achieving a conversion rate of 97 % and a selectivity of 99 % for 1,2-epoxycyclooctane over six consecutive runs without notable loss. Furthermore, the PW-PIL-TB-2PP catalyst could also be used for the oxidation of a wide range of cyclic, linear, and aromatic alkenes. Graphical abstract Poly(ionic liquid)s-loaded polyoxometalates prepared via quaternization reaction are efficient and stable heterogeneous catalysts for clean oxidation of alkenes using H2O2 as the oxidant. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Quaternization reaction Poly(ionic liquid)s Polyoxometalates Alkenes Oxidation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Oxidation of alkenes is a critical reaction for producing epoxy compounds [1], 1,2-diol compounds [2], aldehydes [3], and carboxylic acids [4], which are important raw materials in the chemical industry due to their wide range of applications. One of the primary methods for catalyzing alkene oxidation is the H2O2 oxidation method. H₂O₂ stands out as an exemplary oxidant due to its high active oxygen content, strong oxidizing capacity, and environmentally benign with the generation of water as byproduct. Therefore, the green oxidation of alkenes via H2O2 oxidation methods has attracted increasing attention in recent years [5–8]. Polyoxometalates (POMs) have garnered considerable attention as environmentally friendly catalysts within the catalysis research community [9–12]. Particularly, POMs have been proved to be high-efficiency homogeneous catalysts for the H₂O₂-based oxidation of alkenes [1]. To improve the catalysts recovery and reuse, significant efforts have been made to develop heterogeneous catalysts by immobilizing POMs [13,14]. Traditionally, the POMs were immobilized on various modified silicas and diverse molecular sieves [13,15], suffering from the limited number of silanol (Si–OH) groups on the surface of these carriers, which restricts the loading number of POMs (Fig. 1 (1)). To date, a range of novel carriers have been reported to enhance the loading of POMs, including carbon materials [16], metal oxides [17], organic framework materials [18], and polymeric materials [19]. Considering the limited assortment of carriers, it is still necessary to develop new carriers for POMs and to improve both their loading capacity and reusability. Poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs), characterized by their diverse types of ionic liquids and adjustable structures, coupled with the ease of separation and recovery of multiphase catalysts, are also employed as effective carriers for immobilizing POMs (Fig. 1(2)) [1,20–22]. Shi et al. synthesized tunable hydrophobic mesoporous PILs via free-radical polymerization, with POMs immobilized on these PILs with high dispersion and density. Because of strong cation-anion interactions and the affinity of catalyst with both substrate and oxidant, this system effectively epoxidized cyclooctene, achieving yields over 98 % with stable activity upon recovery [20]. Zhao et al. synthesized thermally stable amphiphilic POM-paired ionic hybrid catalysts via free radical polymerization. Their amphiphilic nature and mesoporous structure resulted in excellent performance, achieving over 99 % selectivity and conversion in the epoxidation of cyclooctene [21]. Leng et al. developed thermally stable, amphiphilic mesoporous POM-based ionic hybrid catalysts via free radical polymerization, achieving 100 % selectivity and 99 % conversion in the epoxidation of cyclooctene [1]. Despite the success of these PILs-based catalysts, the variety of reported PILs prepared through free-radical polymerization is relatively limited. Thus, it is still highly attractive to prepare more diverse and structurally adjustable PILs through alternative methods to expand the range of PILs-based carriers. Compared with free-radical polymerization, quaternization reaction can achieve simultaneous polymerization and ionization, thus offering an additive-free method to prepare PILs [23]. The ionic sites in PILs prepared via quaternization reaction typically reside at the junctions between monomers, existing in the form of pyridine or imidazole salts [24]. PILs prepared through quaternization reaction have been applied in catalysis [25], carbon dioxide fixation [26], radioactive ion and organic dye adsorption [27,28], and other fields [29]. Yu et al. reported an ionic porous organic framework with high ionic density and a nitrogen content of 20.3 wt%, catalyzing the CO2 cycloaddition of propylene oxide with 99 % yield at mild conditions of 25 °C and 0.1 MPa CO2 [26]. Suman et al. synthesized a thermally and chemically robust ionic porous organic polymer, which efficiently captured toxic oxo-anions and anionic dyes, and demonstrated effective photocatalytic degradation of cationic dyes under solar irradiation [30]. Given the relatively limited number of quaternization reaction monomers reported to date, it is imperative to design and synthesize novel quaternization reaction monomers for synthesizing PILs with unique structure and property. To the best of our knowledge, there are currently no reports in the literature on PILs, prepared via quaternization reaction, loaded POMs for catalyzing the oxidation of alkenes using H₂O₂ as the oxidant. Herein, we successfully synthesized a diverse range of quaternization reagents, which effectively reacted with cross-linkers, thereby enable the preparation of a series of PILs microspheres via a one-step quaternization reaction. These PILs exhibited a high loading amount ratio for POMs, which were well-dispersed on the surface of PILs. These catalysts, POMs, especially obtained by loading H3PW12O40 onto PILs, exhibited remarkable activity in the oxidation of cyclooctene using H2O2 as the oxidant. The structural characterization and evaluation of the recycling performance of the reused catalyst revealed that the catalyst possesses high stability and good reusability. As far as we know, this is the first example on using this method to prepare efficient heterogenous catalysts for the oxidation of alkenes. This work broadens the range of carriers for reactive POMs and creates novel catalysts for the oxidation of alkenes to produce useful oxygen-containing compounds. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Reagents N-(3-Aminopropyl)-imidazole (98 %) and 1,4-Phthalaldehyde (98 %) were obtained from Annaiji chemical reagent (Shanghai, China). Glyoxaline (99 %), Cyanuric chloride (99 %) and 1,4-Bis(chloromethyl)benzene (98 %) were obtained from Innochem chemical reagent (Beijing, China). Cyclooctene (95 %) were purchased from Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). 2,4,6-Tris(bromomethyl)mesitylene (98 %) and 1,2,4,5-Tetrakis(Bromomenthyl)benzene (98 %) were obtained from Adamas chemical reagent (Shanghai, China). H3PW12O40 (PW, AR) was purchased from Kunshan Xingbang Tungsten and Molybdenum Technology Co., Ltd (China). H3PMo12O40 (PMo, AR) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (China). H4SiW12O40 (SiW, AR) was obtained from Kermel Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (China). All the reagents are used directly without further pretreatment. 2.2 Synthesis of quaternization reagents 1,4-bis((1H-imidazol-1-yl)methyl)benzene (BB), (1E,1′E)−1,1′-(1,4-phenylene)bis(N-(3-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)propyl)methanimine) (PP), and 2,4,6-tri(1H-imidazol-1-yl)−1,3,5-triazine (TT) The BB was prepared according to the literature with slight modifications [31]. Initially, NaOH (3 g, 75 mmol) was added to a solution of imidazole (4.08 g, 60 mmol) in THF. The resulting suspension was then refluxed at 70 °C for 2 h. Subsequently, 1,4-bis(chloromethyl)benzene (3.51 g, 20 mmol) was added to the residue and stirred at room temperature for 10 h, followed by an additional 14 h of stirring at 70 °C. After filtering the product, BB was obtained by removing the solvent under vacuum. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD): δ 7.71 (s, 2H), 7.23 (s, 4H), 7.07 (s, 2H), 6.96 (s, 2H), 5.19 (s, 4H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CD3OD): δ 137.24 (s), 136.96 (s), 127.99 (s), 127.79 (s), 119.52 (s), 49.75 (s). Theoretical molecular weight of C14H14N4: 238.12. HRMS found C14H15N4: 239.12 [M + H]+. The PP was prepared according to the literature with minor modifications [32]. A mixture of 1,4-phthalaldehyde (10.73 g, 80 mmol) and N-(3-aminopropyl)-imidazole (20 g, 160 mmol) was dissolved in anhydrous MeOH (150 mL) and refluxed for 24 h. Subsequently, the product was obtained by removing the solvent under vacuum. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD): δ 8.34 (s, 1H), 7.81 (s, 2H), 7.67 (s, 1H), 7.16 (s, 1H), 6.96 (s, 1H), 4.14 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 2H), 3.60 (t, J = 6.5 Hz, 2H), 2.30- 2.03 (m, 2H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CD3OD): δ 162.42 (s), 138.05 (s), 137.10 (s), 128.21 (s), 127.76 (s), 119.23 (s), 57.47 (s), 44.49 (s), 31.59 (s). Theoretical molecular weight of C20H24N6: 348.21. HRMS found C20H25N6: 349.21 [M + H]+. The TT was synthesized according to the literature and the structure was accurately confirmed by 1H NMR, 13C NMR and HRMS [33]. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO): δ 9.10 (s, 3H), 8.35 (s, 3H), 7.27 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO): δ 162.57 (s), 138.05 (s), 131.82 (s), 117.84 (s). Theoretical molecular weight of C12H9N9: 279.10. HRMS found C12H10N9: 280.10 [M + H]+. 2.3 Preparation of different catalysts The synthesis of the PILs loaded POMs catalysts is illustrated in Scheme 1 . As a representative example, the synthesis of PIL-TB-2PP support is described (TB=1,2,4,5-Tetrakis(Bromomenthyl)benzene, and the 2 represents the molar ratio of TB: PP=1:2 during the quaternization reaction. Others are similar). Typically, TB (2.29 g, 5 mmol) and PP (3.48 g, 10 mmol) were dissolved in a 100 mL mixture of solvents consisting of 50 mL of ethyl acetate and 50 mL of DMF. The reaction mixture was vigorously stirred at room temperature for 4 h, followed by stirring at 50 °C for 10 h, and then at 90 °C for another 10 h. Upon completion of the reaction, the solid product was filtered, washed with ethyl acetate three times, and dried at 70 °C overnight. For the preparation of the POMs-loaded catalyst, PIL-TB-2PP (2.0 g) and H3PW12O40 (PW, 20 g) or H3PMo12O40 (PMo, 20 g) or H4SiW12O40 (SiW, 20 g) were dissolved in a 200 mL mixture of solvents (consisting of 100 mL of ethanol and 100 mL of deionized water). The mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 24 h. The resulting solid product was filtered, washed with boiled water three times, and dried at 70 °C overnight, yielding the corresponding catalyst of PW-PIL-TB-2PP or PMo-PIL-TB-2PP or SiW-PIL-TB-2PP. Similar synthetic procedures were employed for the preparation of other catalysts, with adjustments made only to the quaternization reagents and cross-linkers (see Scheme S1 and S2 for details). 2.4 Catalysts characterization Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were obtained on a Bruker V70 system with a scan range of 400–4000 cm−1 using anhydrous KBr as pellets. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was conducted with a TGA/DSC 2 analyzer on the Netzsch STA 449 F3 simultaneous thermal analysis system between 30 and 800 °C in N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The BET isotherms were recorded at 77 K with Micromeritics ASAP2460 apparatus. The samples were degassed for 8 h at 120 °C before the measurements. The pore size and volumes distributions were calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) technique and the surface areas were estimated using the BET method. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were recorded on a ZEISS Sigma 300 (10 KV) to assess the particle dimensions and morphology. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained on a FEI Talos F200X. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed on a Rigaku D/MAX-2400 diffractometer scanning 2θ from 5 to 80° Cu Kα radiation obtained at 40 kV and 30 mA was used as the X-ray source. The BET isotherms were recorded at 77 K with Micromeritics TriStar II 3020 apparatus. The samples were degassed for 10 h at 120 °C before the measurements. The XPS spectra were obtained using an Thermo Scientific K-Alpha X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with Al Kα X-rays as the excitation source. 2.5 Catalytic tests The catalytic activity was evaluated in the oxidation of the probe substrate cis-cyclooctene, using H2O2 as the oxidant and acetonitrile as the solvent. In a typical procedure, a mixture comprising cis-cyclooctene (2.5 mmol), acetonitrile (3 mL), H2O2 (30 %, 4 mmol), and the catalyst (0.1 g) was charged into a 20 mL thick-wall pressure bottle and stirred at 70 °C for 4 h. After reaction, the liquid phase was separated by centrifugation and quantitatively analyzed using mesitylene as the internal standard on a gas chromatograph (GC, Agilent 6820) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a capillary column (OV-1701, 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.5 μm). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) tests were conducted to assess the composition and valence states of the elements in the catalysts. The N1s spectrum of PP can be deconvoluted into three peaks at 398.08 eV, 399.92 eV, and 400.68 eV, corresponding to N=C (Schiff base), N-C (imidazole), and N=C (imidazole) bonds, respectively (Fig. 3(a)) [28]. The N1s spectrum of PW-PIL-TB-2PP appears a new peak at 401.54 eV, which can be attributed to the N+=C (imidazole) formed after the quaternization reaction. Upon loading of POMs, the binding energy of N=C (Schiff base) and NC (imidazole) increased by 0.8 and 1.1 eV, respectively, which certified the strong chemical interaction between PW12O40 3− and PILs carriers (Fig. 3(c)) [20,28]. The XPS wide scan spectrum of PW-PIL‐TB-2PP showed the presence of C, N, O, P, and W (Fig. 3(f)), confirming the successful loading of POMs onto PILs. Similarly, the XPS survey spectra of other catalysts also affirmed the successful synthesis of various PILs through quaternization reaction, and the effective loading of POMs onto PILs (Fig. S10). Fig. 4(a) shows the Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) spectra of PIL-TB-2PP and PW-PIL-TB-2PP. For PIL-TB-2PP, the vibrational bands at 1153 and 1635 cm−1 can be assigned to the C-N+ and C=N in the imidazolium rings, respectively [34,35]. Upon loading POMs, characteristic vibration bands for the Keggin structure of PW12O40 3− anion emerged at 1080, 978, 896, and 805 cm−1, assignable to the stretching vibration of the central oxygen ν(P-Oa), terminal oxygen ν(W=Ot), interoctahedral oxygen ν(W-Ob-W), and intraoctahedral oxygen ν(W-Oc-W), respectively [36]. Similar characteristic vibration bands were observed for other catalysts (Fig. S11), such as PMo12O40 3− and SiW12O40 4−. These results also confirm the successful synthesis of PILs via quaternization reaction and the loading of POMs onto PILs. Furthermore, the identical peaks obtained for heterogenized catalysts indicate the preservation of the primary Keggin structure of the POMs after immobilization on PILs, thereby retaining the original properties of the parent catalysts. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements of H3PW12O40, PIL-TB-2PP, and PW-PIL-TB-2PP are presented in Fig. 4(b). The XRD pattern of PIL-TB-2PP displays broad reflections at 2θ of 23°, indicating its predominantly amorphous nature. Conversely, the pattern of pristine heteropoly acid exhibits typical diffraction peaks characteristic of the Keggin structure. After immobilization H3PW12O40 onto the PIL-TB-2PP network, the distinct crystalline peaks of the H3PW12O40 vanished, likely due to some disordering of its amorphous material structure trigger by the quaternization reaction of the quaternization reagents and cross-linkers [37], and POM is relatively uniformly distributed in the carrier [38]. Similar results were observed for other PILs and catalysts, as depicted in Fig. S12. The thermal stability of catalysts was assessed using thermogravimetric analysis (TG), and the weight loss curves are depicted in Fig. 4(c). PIL-TB-2PP exhibited slight weight loss from room temperature to 100 °C, probably attributing to desorption of the physical adsorbed trace amounts of solvents and water in the pores. A significant weight loss occurred in the range of 250–400 °C, associating with the degradation of the organic polymeric framework. Upon loading POMs, the thermal stability of PIL-TB-2PP improved markedly, with PW-PIL-TB-2PP starting to decompose at around 400 °C. The TG curves of other PILs and catalysts are presented in Fig. S13, indicating that all PILs exhibit good thermal stability suitable for using as carriers and the catalysts derived from various PILs loaded with POMs demonstrate commendable thermal stability. The textural properties of different PILs and catalysts were also examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and N2 sorption isotherms. SEM images revealed that the surfaces of different PILs prepared via quaternization reactions appeared relatively smooth. However, upon loading with POMs, the catalyst surfaces became noticeably rougher (Figs. 5 and S14). This observation infers the successful loading of POMs onto the PILs, thereby altering their morphological structure. The alteration in catalyst morphology invariably results in a change in the specific surface area. For instance, the surface area of PIL-TB-2PP was very small (<1 m2g−1). Remarkably, the surface area of PW-PIL-TB-2PP increased significantly to 9.9 m2g−1 after the loading of POMs. The textural properties of other catalysts were shown in Table 1 , the low specific surface area of these catalysts (<15 m2g−1) is in line with previous reports on the PILs prepared through quaternization reaction [39–42]. The black portion in the TEM images of catalysts indicates that the introduced POMs had been dispersed in the PILs (Fig. S15). The elemental mapping images further confirm the successful loading of POMs into the PILs, with the POMs uniformly distributed into PIL-TB-2PP (Fig. 5). Moreover, the significant reduction in Br anion content from 40.44 % to 0.22 % suggests that POMs were immobilized into the PIL through an ion-exchange process with Br anions, as depicted in Scheme S2. Table 1 provides details about the loading amounts of POMs on various PILs. The PILs synthesized via quaternization reactions exhibited a higher loading capacity for POMs (loading amount ratio up to 534 %), which is close to 6 times that of the supported H3PW12O40 produced through free radical polymerization method as reported previously [20]. The loading amounts of POMs on PILs prepared by quaternization reactions also show substantial differences due to variations in the structures of quaternization reagents and cross-linkers. Compared with the quaternization reagents with shorter molecular, such as BB (12.43 Å) and TT (12.89 Å) (Fig. 2 ), the PIL, synthesized using PP with longer molecular size (25.32 Å), exhibited much higher loading amounts of POMs (up to 455 %, 3.6 and 1.7 times higher than the corresponding formers, entries 1–3, Table 1). The greater molecular size of quaternization reagents allows for a longer distance between the quaternary ammonium sites after the quaternization reaction, facilitating the loading of POMs. Moreover, the nature of the heteropoly acid itself influences the loading amount. Under the same carrier of PIL-TB-2PP, as the acidity of the heteropoly acid decreased, the loading amounts of POMs decreased from 455 % to 273 % (entries 3–4, Table 1). This trend arises from the fact that stronger acidity promotes ionic exchange reactions between the heteropoly acid and PILs. Furthermore, under identical quaternization reagents and cross-linkers, increasing the molar ratio of quaternization reagents to cross-linkers from 2 to 4 resulted in an increase in the loading of POMs from 455 % to 534 % (entries 2 and 4, Table 1). This increase is attributed to the higher number of quaternary ammonium sites. The high loading capacity of PILs with POMs is anticipated to offer promising applications in the areas of catalysis for active metal loading, carbon dioxide fixation, and radioactive ion adsorption. 3.2 Catalytic activity The catalytic activity of various PILs supported POMs catalysts was assessed in the oxidation of the probe substrate of cyclooctene with aqueous H2O2 as an oxidant and acetonitrile as a solvent. As shown in Table 2 , up to 99 % cyclooctene conversion and 92 % selectivity to the target 1,2-epoxycyclooctane could be attained in the presence of the PW-PIL-TB-2PP catalyst (entry 2). However, almost no reaction took place without H2O2, even doubled the amount of the PW-PIL-TB-2PPcatalyst (entry 1). This finding reveals that the oxidation of cyclooctene proceeds via the generation of reactive oxygen species by H2O2 in the presence of catalyst [43]. Note that no reaction took place as well in the presence of H2O2 but the absence of catalyst (not shown), showing the importance of the H2O2 in activation of the catalyst. Among the PILs supported heteropoly acids, PW-PIL-TB-2PP presented the best performance, followed by PMo-PIL-TB-2PP and SiW-PIL-TB-2PP (entries 2–4, Table 2). Such finding may associate with that the electrons of the alkene can fill the vacant 4f, 4d, and 5 s orbitals of Mo for PMo-based catalyst, resulting in a comparatively more stable intermediate than with PW-based catalysts, where the electrons of the alkene can only fill the vacant 5d and 6 s orbitals of W [44]. Consequently, the transfer of active oxygen to the C=C moiety of the alkene in the latter catalyst is retarded. The rather poor performance of SiW-PIL-TB-2PP (with only 28 % cyclooctene conversion) is consistent with research by Ding et al. [44], which is due to the decomposition of H2O2 by SiW12O40 4− and the extremely low specific surface area of catalyst (<1 m2g−1) [45]. The catalytic performance of the PILs supported H3PW12O40 catalyst also effected by the quaternization reagents and cross-linkers (entries 2, 5–9, Table 2). The conversion of cyclooctene in the trend of PW-PIL-TB-2BB<PW-PIL-TB-2TT<PW-PIL-TB-4PP ≈ PW-PIL-TB-2PP, which is line with the trend of their phosphotungstate loading amount shown in Table 1. It seems that high loading amount of phosphotungstate in the catalyst benefits the conversion of cyclooctene. This is because high amount of PW12O40 3− could be converted to the catalytic active species of {PO4[WO(O2)2]4}3− under the oxidation of H2O2, and thus contributed to their high activity [46]. Nonetheless, high amount of phosphotungstate would result in the further transformation of the target 1,2-epoxycyclooctane into the byproducts of cyclooctane-1,2-diol and 2-hydroxycyclooctan-1-one under the same reaction conditions, as up to 99 % selectivity to the target 1,2-epoxycyclooctane was obtained over PW-PIL-TB-2BB and PW-PIL-TB-2TT, while up to above 7 % cyclooctane-1,2-diol and 2-hydroxycyclooctan-1-one byproducts were detected over PW-PIL-TB-4PP and PW-PIL-TM-2PP. Clearly, to obtain high yield of 1,2-epoxycyclooctane from cyclooctene epoxidation, it requires to suppress the over transformation of target product. Note that all the PIL supported PW catalysts presented superior cyclooctene conversion and 1,2-epoxycyclooctane selectivity than that of the pure PW, which is a homogeneous catalytic reaction. To our delight, high yield of 1,2-epoxycyclooctane (up to above 97 %) could be attained via optimizing the catalyst amount (Table 2, entries 2, 4 and 5, Fig. 6 a), reaction temperature (Fig. 6b) and reaction time (Fig. 6c). The catalytic performance of the PW-PIL-TB-2PP catalyst is also affected by the amount of H2O2. Increasing H₂O₂ amount from 1 to 8 mmol led to a rapid increase in cyclooctene conversion from 47 to 99 %, accompanied by a gradual decrease in 1,2-epoxycyclooctane selectivity from 99 to 90 % (Fig. 6d), achieving a maximum 1,2-epoxycyclooctane yield of 96 % at around 1.5–2 times of H2O2 to the substrate. Notably, the turnover frequency (TOF) value for the epoxidation of cyclooctene over PW-PIL-TB-2PP catalyst is much higher than that of the heterogeneous catalysts reported previously (Table S1), demonstrating the outstanding performance of the PILs supported POMs catalyst. Encouraged by the above results, the scope of the PW-PIL-TB-2PP catalyst for other substrates was investigated, and the results are summarized in Table 3 . For cyclic alkenes, the epoxide products are prone to ring-opening reactions, with the main by-products being 1,2-diols. By reducing the reaction temperature and the amount of hydrogen peroxide, the selectivity for epoxide compounds can reach 99 % (entries 1–6). For aromatic alkenes, in addition to the formation of epoxide compounds, due to the presence of competing reactions such as C = C bond cleavage and isomerization reactions, the generation of aldehyde and ketone compounds was also observed (entries 7–10). In a word, the catalyst demonstrated versatility in the oxidation of cyclic, linear, and aromatic alkenes using H₂O₂ as the oxidant [47]. The reusability of the PW-PIL-TB-2PP catalyst was assessed through the oxidation of cyclooctene. After each cycle, the catalyst was separated from the reaction system by centrifugation and dried at 60 °C. The results depicted in Fig. 7 (a) and (b) demonstrate that the catalyst exhibited excellent stability during six consecutive reuse cycles, maintaining cyclooctene conversion and 1,2-epoxycyclooctane selectivity without appreciable deactivation no matter at high or low cyclooctene conversion. FT-IR (Fig. 8 a) spectroscopy and XRD (Fig. 8b) characterization of the used catalyst showed that the structure of the PW-PIL-TB-2PP catalyst remained essentially unchanged after six reuses, further supporting the good stability of the catalyst under reaction conditions. In addition, the hot filtration experiment confirms the heterogeneous catalysis of PW-PIL-TB-2PP catalyst in the catalytic oxidation of cyclooctene, as no further conversion of cyclooctene could be detected after filtering of the catalyst (Fig. 7c). Obviously, the above findings showcase the novel catalytic performance of the PILs supported H3PW12O40 catalyst, which holds promising potential for industrial applications. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a new quaternization reagent PP that has not been previously reported in the literature was synthesized and a series of novel PILs were prepared via a one-step quaternization reaction using PP reacted with cross-linkers. POMs were subsequently loaded into these PILs through ion exchange method to synthesize innovative catalysts, and their catalytic activity was evaluated for the oxidation of alkenes. The catalysts, especially PW-PIL-TB-2PP, exhibited remarkable activity for the oxidation of various cyclic, linear, and aromatic alkenes, due to the high loading amount ratio of the PILs for POMs. And the novel PW-PIL-TB-2PP catalyst could be facilely recovered and reused for six runs without significant loss in catalytic activity. The high loading capacity of the PILs for POMs is likely owing to the high content of quaternary ammonium sites and the long distance between them. This work not only provides a simple method for the preparation of novel PILs without additional additives, such as metal or free-radical initiator, but also broadens the range of carriers for reactive POMs and creates novel catalysts for the oxidation of alkenes. Additionally, this study may also offer valuable guidance for the design and preparation of heterogeneous materials with outstanding performances, such as active metal loading, carbon dioxide fixation, and radioactive ion adsorption. coredata.dc:description: A novel quaternization reagent of (1E,1′E)-1,1′-(1,4-phenylene)bis(N-(3-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)propyl)methanimine) (PP) was synthesized and used for the preparation of a series of poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs) via the quaternization reaction. These PILs were subsequently loaded with polyoxometalates (POMs) to create innovative catalysts for the oxidation of alkenes. Comprehensive structural analysis of the catalysts showed that these PILs exhibited a high loading amount ratio of up to 542 % for POMs, which were well-dispersed on the surface of PILs. The PILs loaded POMs catalysts, especially for PW-PIL-TB-2PP with H3PW12O40 as the POMs, displayed remarkable activity and stability in oxidizing cyclooctene, achieving a conversion rate of 97 % and a selectivity of 99 % for 1,2-epoxycyclooctane over six consecutive runs without notable loss. Furthermore, the PW-PIL-TB-2PP catalyst could also be used for the oxidation of a wide range of cyclic, linear, and aromatic alkenes.
